This Is Going to Hurt: The Indispensable Value of the NHS

06/04/2022

Ed Halford reviews the seven part BBC drama about the challenging life of a labour ward doctor

Image by British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)

By Kyle Boulton

The following review contains spoilers

The only occasion the public is given a glimpse of the hard work our NHS nurses and doctors undertake is when they catch a short clip of the insides of a hospital in rolling news coverage or are unfortunate enough to visit the hospital themselves. During the pandemic, many of us passed the time by binge-watching Netflix box sets and listening to Chris Whittyâ€™s miserable forecasts in daily press conferences.

Meanwhile, our NHS staff battled on, increasing their hours, and working long days that challenged their mental fortitude. When you were sitting in your living room digesting the latest Covid death statistics, the carnage Covid inflicted may have seemed very distant. Despite Adam Kay writing his bestselling memoir before the pandemic, the BBCâ€™s decision to use this as the basis for a seven-part series offers the public the chance to learn more about the gruelling work of NHS doctors.

Film critics regularly summarise a movie as a â€œmust watchâ€ but over time the meaning of this compliment has been diluted. Anything which is not subpar is frequently attributed as constituting a â€œmust watch.â€ However, Iâ€™m going to be my own worst enemy- This is Going to Hurt is a â€œmust watch.â€ In the past, medical dramas such as Holby City and Casualty have left me feeling uneasy and wondering what the point is of dramas which have a never-ending plot. The blood and gore arenâ€™t the problem but the fact that Karen with the broken leg has been checked and left the hospital before you are given time to develop any sort of emotional attachment with the patients.

Week after week, the content is the same. A poor patient ends up in the operating theatre, while a work colleague worries whether their relationship with another colleague is verging on â€˜unprofessionalâ€™. This is Going to Hurt is different, as there is no reluctance to tackle the issues which are responsible for NHS staff feeling drained, beleaguered, and unsupported.

Ben Whishaw, winner of the British Independent Film Award for his performance in My Brother Tom (2001) and known to avid fans of James Bond as Q, plays the role of the protagonist Adam perfectly. He manages to provide light relief to the horrific scenes in the obstetrics and gynaecology ward by executing dry wit with precision and in a delicate way, that is not insensitive to the labour complications in the background.

Adam is a junior doctor who is always busy and rushed off his feet. To describe the hospital in the series as understaffed would be an understatement given that Adam is forced to neglect his best man stag-do duties to keep the ward operational. Early on, we are introduced to Shruti (Ambika Mod), who is initially an incapable trainee Adam is tasked with teaching. Desperate to learn but immediately thrust into a chaotic working environment where nobody has time to ask, â€œAre you okay?â€, Shruti's mental health quickly starts to deteriorate.

Spending 97-hour weeks in a labour ward is demanding, let alone when you are suffering inside. Throughout the series, Adam is portrayed as a person who is not yet confident in his sexuality. Greg (Tom Pritchard) is a caring and understanding lover and encourages Adam to be transparent about his homosexuality to his parents and work colleagues. Whishaw manages to capture Adamâ€™s frank awkwardness around colleagues and draws attention to the difficulty in breaking taboos and contravening social norms around those you arenâ€™t close with.

Adam is unlucky enough to have a mother who keeps reminding him of bygone childhood romances, as she prefers to remain blissfully ignorant to her sonâ€™s boyfriend. It is only when Greg places concerted pressure on Adam to bring his work â€˜friendsâ€™ to their disastrous engagement party that many of them find out about his secret boyfriend. The series very skilfully and subtly highlights how coming to terms with oneâ€™s own sexuality can lead to personal identity crises and a fear that you may not be accepted by those around you.

Episode six is the penultimate episode and reinforces the very real consequences of not providing sufficient welfare to doctors, who experience emotionally draining days and are given little time to wind down. The event you didnâ€™t expect is Shrutiâ€™s suicide. Rarely is attention in the media given to suicides amongst health professionals but since 2011 the ONS (Office for National Statistics) has consistently recorded around 30 a year. Kayâ€™s memoir was written before Covid-19 arrived, so working conditions for doctors across the NHS have undoubtedly worsened.

Shrutiâ€™s suicide emphasises the importance of having empathetic mentors in the workplace, as when she reaches out to Miss Houghton (Ashley McGuire) for advice she is bluntly told that the job wonâ€™t get any easier. It is easy to scapegoat Adam for failing to look out for Shruti but the root cause of the suicide is the lack of a support network for doctors. Doctors are forced to stray away from forming any emotional connection with their patients and yet Adamâ€™s well-choreographed flashbacks to past mistakes demonstrate the harmful mental toll the job inflicts.

The drama manages to serve as an educational resource, as well as providing a plot which fails to disappoint. The series serves as a stark reminder of why the NHS is of indispensable value to the British public. Unfortunately, the value of the expertise and care our health professionals deliver is not reflected by their low pay or dire work-life balance.

Editorâ€™s Note: This Is Going to Hurt is available to stream on BBC iPlayer
